analyzed: theḥ apadāna  eka pad umiya vagga
translated: The Elders’ Birth Stories🔽. The Chapter with Ekapundarika
The Elder who Gave a Handful of Grass
“Not far from the Himalayas,
there is a mountain named Lambaka;
The Fully Enlightened One named Upatissa,
was walking in the open air.
At that time I was a hunter,
in the forest, in the jungle;
Having seen that God of Gods,
the Self-Existent One, the Unconquered One.
With a confident mind,
at that time of that Great Seer;

analyzed: nisīdana attham buddhassa  tiṇa muṭṭhi madāsaha
translated: For the purpose of sitting down for the Buddha,🔽I gave a handful of grass.
Having given to the God of Gods,
I further purified my mind;
Having worshipped the Fully Enlightened One,
I departed facing north.
Not long after I had gone,
the King of Beasts killed me;
Having been killed by the Lion,
I died right there.
The deed I did in the presence of,
the Best Buddha, the Unsullied One;
Having been well released like a flood,
I went to the world of the gods.
There was a beautiful sacrificial post there,
made by the power of my meritorious deeds;
With a thousand branches, a hundred spokes,
with flags, made of green (jade).
The light of the sun and moon

analyzed: sa tarasi iva u k gataḥ
translated: rose up like a net of stars.
Surrounded by celestial maidens,
I was intoxicated, lustful.
Having fallen from the world of the gods,
urged on by the root of merit,
having come to the human state,
I attained the destruction of the pollutants.
For ninety-four aeons
I gave a seat,
I do not know of a bad destination,
this is the fruit of the handful of grass.
The four analytical insights,

original: kataṁ buddhassa sāsanaṁ”.🔽Itthaṁ sudaṁ āyasmā tiṇamuṭṭhidāyako thero imā gāthāyo abhāsitthāti.
analyzed: katam buddhassa sāsana  ittham sudam āyasmā tiṇamuṭṭhidāyakaḥ theraḥ imāḥ gāthāyaḥ abhāsittha ati
translated: The Buddha’s instruction has been carried out.”🔽Thus the elder Tiṇamuṭṭhidāyaka recited these verses.
The account of the elder Tiṇamuṭṭhidāyaka is the eighth.
